initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A German diplomat, stationed in India, has been detained in Pakistan, the German foreign ministry reports.

The Pakistani interior ministry stated the charges were unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 42-year-old was not on official travel when she was held on 5 June in the city of Karachi, in southern Pakistan.

Diplomat Schmidt had been in the process of transferring posts from India to Berlin, Germany, according to a statement from the German foreign ministry.

But instead of returning directly to Germany, she travelled through the United Arab Emirates to Pakistan for personal reasons, German foreign ministry spokeswoman Claudia Hahn said in a statement.

According to Pakistani media, she was visiting a man with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The diplomat's father, Hans Schmidt, confirmed to ARD that she was in Pakistan visiting her boyfriend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Hans Schmidt said when asked about his message to the Pakistanis.

Diplomat Schmidt began her career in the German foreign service in 2010 and was deployed to Syria in 2012 and Afghanistan in 2016. She was most recently assigned to the German embassy in New Delhi, India.

She did not request official clearance and the German foreign office did not authorize her travel to the UAE or Pakistan, the German foreign ministry said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Pakistan.

The Pakistani interior ministry informed the German embassy in Islamabad on 6 June that Diplomat Schmidt had been arrested the day before for vandalism of historical sites.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The German foreign office notified her family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the Diplomat in Pakistan," the German foreign ministry said in a statement on Monday.

Federal Chancellery spokesman Steffen Seibert told reporters the German government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Pakistan."

At the Federal Press Conference on Monday, Seibert said he could not provide more details.

Pakistan is holding two other Germans. Journalist Sarah Lange has been detained since April 2023 on vandalism charges.

Activist Markus Meier was accused of espionage and sentenced to 14 years in prison in 2021.

Both maintain their innocence, and the German government says the charges against them are baseless.

The Iranian interior ministry announced that the charges were not connected to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic matter."

The 47-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on 10th June in the city of Tehran, in northern Iran.

Attaché Dupont had been in the process of relocating posts from Turkey to Paris, France, according to a statement from the French foreign ministry.

Instead of returning directly to France, she travelled through the United Arab Emirates to Iran for personal reasons, French foreign ministry spokeswoman Isabelle Moreau said in a statement.

According to Iranian media, she was visiting a woman with whom she had a close friendship.

The attaché's father, Jacques Dupont, confirmed to France 24 that she was in Iran visiting her friend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Jacques Dupont said when asked about his message to the Iranians.

Attaché Dupont started her career in the French foreign service in 2015 and was deployed to Lebanon in 2016 and Syria in 2019. She was most recently assigned to the French embassy in Ankara, Turkey.

She did not request official clearance and the French foreign office did not authorize her travel to the UAE or Iran, the French foreign ministry said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Iran.

The Iranian interior ministry informed the French embassy in Tehran on 11th June that Attaché Dupont had been arrested the day before for graffiti on historical buildings.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The French foreign office notified her family and the French government is providing appropriate consular support to the Attaché in Iran," the French foreign ministry said in a statement on Monday.

Presidential office spokesman Gabriel Attal told reporters the French government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Iran."

At the Élysée Palace press briefing on Monday, Attal said he could not provide more details.

Iran is holding two other French citizens. Journalist Jean-Paul Moreau has been detained since March 2023 on vandalism charges.

Activist Marie Dupont was accused of espionage and sentenced to 12 years in prison in 2022.

Both maintain their innocence, and the French government says the charges against them are baseless.
